conversation.content: Don't call anyone, please, I just need a minute to catch my breath here on the ground. [strained]
Already calling 911.
[firmly] Cancel it. I'm Marcus Chen, I run Apex Industries, and the last thing I need is headlines about me collapsing on Fifth Avenue during market hours.
[calmly] Your left arm is shaking and you're sweating through a suit that probably costs more than my car, so I'm keeping them on the line.
[controlled breathing] It's just exhaustion, fourteen-hour days for three weeks straight closing the Singapore merger. My driver is two blocks away, I can make it.
Sure, exhaustion.
You don't understand what happens when the market sees weakness—stock prices, board confidence, everything I've built for twenty years can crumble from one photograph. [gasps]
[steadily] I'm a cardiac nurse heading home from a double shift, so actually I understand exactly what's happening to your body right now, Mr. Chen.
[quieter] A nurse. Of course. Look, I know what this looks like, but I've handled worse than a little chest tightness.
[matter-of-fact] The ambulance is three minutes out, and you're going to sit here with me, breathing slowly, not arguing, while I monitor your pulse.
My father died of a heart attack at fifty-eight, same age I am now, same goddamn street corner actually. [bitter laugh]
[gently] That's quite a coincidence, but you're not going to die today, not on my watch, not on this corner.
He was closing a deal too, rushed out of a meeting, never made it to the hospital. I swore I'd be different.
[firmly] You are different—you're accepting help, even if reluctantly, and that ambulance is pulling up right now.
What's your name? I should at least know who's saving me from my own stupidity. [exhales slowly]
Diana Morrison, and you're not stupid, just human like the rest of us. [reassuring]
[weakly] Diana, when this gets out, and it will, my competitors are going to circle like sharks. Twenty years of being untouchable, gone.
[clearly] Twenty years from now, you'll either be telling this story at dinner parties or your kids will be telling it at your funeral—your choice.
[surrendering] Alright, Diana Morrison, cardiac nurse with terrible bedside manner, help me up. Let's go to the hospital. [sighs]
Best decision you've made all day, Mr. Chen, maybe all year.

scenario: A powerful CEO collapses on a city sidewalk from a possible heart attack, and a passing off-duty cardiac nurse stops to help despite his protests about publicity.
